items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This is an update to the Flood Alert issued yesterday 21/08/24 at 4:44 PM. The tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning 23/08/24  is expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions and spring tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The high water level is expected to reach 1.22mAOD at 12:24 AM with southerly force 6 winds. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Thursday 22 August.  

High water at Falmouth is at 8.12pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas.  

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas along the tidal river Helford and exposed coastal locations including Portmellon seafront, Mevagissey Harbour area, and Portholland.   

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.65m AOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.11m - 0.13m above the tide table level.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Lands End to Lizard Point
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Thursday 22 August. 

High water at Newlyn is at 7.30pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 4 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas. 

Locations particularly at risk include Mousehole, Newlyn, Penzance, Longrock, Marazion, Praa Sands and Porthleven harbour. 

Large waves and spray are likely so take care near the coast.  

Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 3.03m AOD.  Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.11m - 0.13m above the tide table level.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast from today, Thursday 22/08/2024, and over the coming days. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible between 6am and 10.30am on Thursday 22/08/2024, and again on Friday 23/08/24 between 7.45am and 11am. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast at Bridlington, particularly at the Lifeboat Station. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening tide on the Thursday 22 August.  

High water at Plymouth is at 8:43pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.86m AOD.  

Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 0.11m - 0.13m above tide table level.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
"River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.52mAOD at 05:30 on 22/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 17 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 22/08/24, or as the situation changes."

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding is possible between 6.30am and 8.30am today, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 2 days, peaking this evening Thursday 22/08/24. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks. 
Sharpness 9.9 to 10.3m at 23:15 on 22/08/2024, and 9.3 to 9.9m at 11:30 on 23/08/2024. 
This morning’s tide, 22/08/24, peaked at Sharpness at 10.1m.
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tides on Thursday 22nd August and Friday 23rd August. High water at Ilfracombe on Thursday evening is at 21:00 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
 
Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 120mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Thursday evening is 5.26 mAOD, this is 0.12 metres above astronomical tide level. 
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is 5.04 mAOD, this is 0.16 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. The first peak high water level at West Bay Harbour is at 9:00 PM this evening 21/08/24 with a level of 2.50 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Thursday mornings tide 22/08/24 will not quite reach our threshold for a flood alert,  but tomorrow evenings tide at 9:43PM will exceed threshold with a predicted level of 2.52 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Tide levels will start dropping from Friday mornings tide onwards. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. People in the areas should consider taking action now. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 22/08/2024.   
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 2:00 PM on 22/08/2024 at the following location:
Rock Park, peaking around 2:00 PM
Hale Village, peaking around 2:30 PM.
Flooding of property is not expected.
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.   
This message will be updated this afternoon, 22/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 2 days, peaking Thursday evening 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.3 to 7.6m at 22:00 on 22/08/2024 and 7.0 to 7.4m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8.0m at 22:15 on 22/08/2024 and 7.4 to 7.8m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024. 
This morning’s tide, 22/08/24, peaked at Newport at 7.3m and at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.7m.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 2pm on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides and  strong winds this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 13:45 PM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Further flooding is possible overnight for the high tide at 02:00 23/08/24 and into Saturday 24/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.
We have closed flood gates at St. Georges Quay, Lancaster.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths are possible, property flooding is not expected 
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of  7.88 mAODN at 9.15 PM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly strong breeze force 5 winds.   Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. 
No property flooding is expected.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
After the high tide this evening‚ the weather is more settled, and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 23/08/2024

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 22/08/2024.  
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 2:45 PM on 22/08/2024 at the following locations:  
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 3:00 PM 
Eastford Road, peaking around 3:15 PM  
Arpley Bridge, Knutsford Road, and Howley, peaking around 3:30 PM 
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. We are also expecting the Flood Alert level to be met during the early hours of the morning Saturday 24/08/2024.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 22/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide this afternoon, 22/08/2024.
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but the current forecast anticipates the flood alert level will be met during the high tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 1:45 PM 22/08/2024. Flooding of property is not expected. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further Flood Alerts. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 22/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Elmdale, Chepstow
items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as strong winds may cause a tidal surge for this evening’s tide. A series of high tides are due over the next 2 days. High tides may impact properties and roads in and around Elmdale, Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 22:00 on 22/08/2024 and 7.0m to 7.4m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8.0m at 22:15 on 22/08/2024 and 7.4 to 7.8m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides. Wave and spray overtopping is possible today, Thursday 22/08/2024, between 6.30am and 8.30am. This could cause some localised flooding. Areas most at risk of flooding include Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the coming days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as the waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 6.15am and 9.30am today, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast between 7:15am to 11:15am, tomorrow morning, 23/08/24.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4:62 mAODN at 9.15am, on Friday 23 August 2024, which is 0.07m below tide tables, wind Force 8, South-Westernly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Saturday 24 August 2024 at 10:15 am is currently below the Flood Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 11.30 am tomorrow, Friday 23 August 2024.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 9:30 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 7.76 mAODN with south-westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024 with a level of 7.67 mAODN with south-westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Portishead and Portbury Dock
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of  7.88 mAODN at 9.15 PM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly force 5 winds.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Portishead Point and Avonmouth.
After the high tide this evening‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 13:45 PM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Further flooding is possible overnight for the 02:00 tide, 23/08/2024 and into Saturday 24/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days
Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Thursday 22 August.  

High water at St Ives is at 8.00pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 2.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.  

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at St Ives is 3.92m AOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.12m - 0.16m above the tide table level.

items.description: South Devon Estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible during the evening high tide on Thursday 22nd August. High water at Plymouth on Thursday evening is at 20:45 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
 
Force 4 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 140mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Thursday evening is 2.87 mAOD, this is 0.14 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 13:45 PM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Further flooding is possible overnight for the 02:00AM tide on 23/08/2024 and into Saturday 24/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Thursday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 22/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.07 m. The total forecast tide is 6.10 metres Chart Datum (3.05 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Thursday afternoon's tide at 14:00 on 22/08/2024 is forecast to be 4 cm higher (3.09 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are predicted to continue each high tide until Saturday 24/08/2024. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 22/08/2024.

items.description: Coast at Barrow in Furness
items.message: High tides, strong winds and large waves today may lead to flooding. The highest tide level at Barrow in Furness is expected at 01:45 PM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include the Coastline at Barrow in Furness. Further flooding is possible during high tides until the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, Gloucestershire, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.67 mAODN at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly force 7 winds.
Please note: The high tide on the evening of 21st August does not meet flood alert criteria.
Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth including Aust and Old Passage.
No property flooding is expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled, and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge from broader weather systems over the UK. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 4:45AM and 5:15AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:15AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:15AM and 07:15AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides at Porlock Weir.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024 with a level of 6.41 mAODN with westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 8:45 AM on 21/08/2024, with a level of 6.19 mAODN and south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This flood alert is expected to remain in force during this high tide sequence up to and including the high tide at 22:30 on 23/08/2024. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides for today but expected to issue Flood Alerts on Friday and over the weekend. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: High tides, strong winds and large waves today may lead to flooding. The highest tide level at North Morecambe Bay is expected at 01:45 PM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. We expect to see similar impacts from the high tides until Saturday 24/08/2024. We have closed flood gates at Arnside promenade. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
High tides and strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:00AM and 06:00AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The areas most likely to be affected are Newbiggin Bay North Promenade and Beadnell Harbour Road North.  

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:00AM and 06:45AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:45AM and 07:45AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Arpley Bridge, Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Warning was issued due to the high tide during the early hours of this morning 22/08/2024.
We do not anticipate the flood warning level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but the current forecast anticipates the flood warning level will be met during the high tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. 
Flooding of property is currently expected on parts of Chester Road, Arpley Road and underneath Arpley Railway Bridge from 03:30 AM on 23/08/2024.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further Flood Alerts and Flood Warnings. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 22/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message:
High tides and strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 04:30AM and 05:15AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Berwick between bridges. 

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 04:45AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:30AM and 06:45AM, 23/08/2024. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message: We do not expect flooding during the high tide this afternoon, which is expected to peak at 02:15 PM. However, a higher tide tonight, at 02:30am on 23/08/2024, may result in further flooding.  High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Coastline from Gretna to Silloth. We have closed flood gates at Skinburness Marsh. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening in response to a high tide on 21/08/2024 at 8.00 PM at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The forecast high water is at 8:00 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 6.77 mAODN with southerly moderate breeze force 4 winds. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

We will be monitoring the high tide and closing gates at Brean and Weston-super-Mare as required.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 2 days with tides peaking this evening 22/08/2024. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. High Tides may impact properties and roads including garages at Brockweir. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 22:00 on 22/08/2024 and 7.0m to 7.4m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8.0m at 22:15 on 22/08/2024 and 7.4 to 7.8m at 10:30 on 23/08/2024. 
This morning’s tide, 22/08/24, peaked at Newport at 7.3m and at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.7m.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Coast at Duddon estuary
items.message: We do not expect flooding during the high tide this afternoon, which is expected to peak at 13:45 PM. However, a high tide, strong winds and large waves may lead to further flooding during the high tide tonight, which will peak at 02:15 AM on 23/08/24. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Duddon estuary including Haverigg, Millom Marsh, Foxfield, Sandside and Dunnerholme. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message: We do not expect flooding during the high tide this afternoon, which is expected to peak at 02:15 PM. However, the following high tide tonight, which will peak at 02:30 AM on 23/08/24, may result in further flooding.  Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven. We have closed flood gates at Flimby and Well Lane Maryport. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cumbrian coastline from Gretna to Silloth including Port Carlisle, Skinburness and Rockcliffe
Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to high tides and surge on the coast. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Flooding of coastal roads is possible this morning between 5.15am and 9.15am and again this evening between 7.45pm and 10.30pm. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to rise and may have caused flooding to low lying land and roads. The rain is expected to continue until mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any warnings in the area. Further rain is expected through tonight 22/08/24 into tomorrow morning 23/08/24.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to rise and may have caused flooding to low lying land and roads. The rain is expected to continue until mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any warnings in the area. Further rain is expected through tonight 22/08/24 into tomorrow morning 23/08/24.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
Due to overnight rain lake levels are expected to continue rising, causing flooding in the area.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon but further rain is expected overnight tonight 22/8/24 into tomorrow morning 23/8/24.  Lake levels are expected to be high until 3:00 PM on 24/08/2024.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site  .

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with campsite staff.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg
items.message: We do not expect flooding during the high tide this afternoon, which is expected to peak at 02:00 PM. However, a high tide, strong winds and large waves may lead to further flooding  during the high tide tonight, which will peak at 02:30 AM on 23/08/24.   Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg including Ravenglass and Annaside. We will close flood gates at Ravenglass. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast. Flooding is possible from today, Thursday 22/08/2024 between 8am and 11.15am. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on Thursday 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Severn Beach
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.67 mAODN at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly force 7 winds.
Please note: The high tide on the evening of 21st August does not meet flood alert criteria.
Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.
No property flooding is expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 22/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Areas most at risk include Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tides of Thursday 22 August and Friday 23 August.  

High water at Falmouth is at 8.12pm on Thursday and 8:56pm on Friday.  

Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds are forecast to cause flooding of waterside locations and roads.   

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Devoran, Calenick, Truro and the A390 at Tresillian. 

The tidal gates at Flushing will be closed.  

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.  

Detailed tidal information for those who use it:  

Thursday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.65m AOD.  

Friday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.48m AOD.  

Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 0.11m - 0.13m above tide table level.
